SAM:Â  So, Marionette is a model and view layer that sits on top of Backbone. If youâ€™ve even used Backbone you pretty quickly realize that render does nothing in their view class. And so, you end up having to roll your own view layer. Marionette is the missing view and application layer from Backbone. So, you just stack Marionette on top and you use Marionette. You use Marionette application, Marionette Wreqr or Radio to basically give you the building blocks for your application. In the current 2.0 form itâ€™s very un-opinionated which makes it very friendly for companies and developers that want to program to actually be able to program. But it lets you iteratively add Marionette to your project, because it is so un-opinionated. So, if you would have a website that would be a bunch of jQuery and maybe a little bit of Backbone or a little bit of anything, you can work on refactoring your code to be Marionette or to be more Backbone just by adding it incrementally, which is an easier sell for a lot of people than saying, â€œWell, we need to rewrite everything because weâ€™re going to use Angular or weâ€™re going to use Ember.â€ Even though both of those do have ways to add incrementally, Iâ€™ve found that adding Marionette in pieces is a very painless experience and it actually helps you improve the overall quality of your code. Itâ€™s like, â€œOkay, well we can solve this because weâ€™re going to release a new major version.â€ So, it doesnâ€™t matter if you had rolled your own. You can now basically, when you upgrade, use our implementation. There were a lot of features that we added in 1.x that got obviously brought over such as behaviors, which is a new concept for Marionette. I would say the biggest new concept. And behaviors are a solution to extend the hell. Iâ€™m sure youâ€™ve seen JavaScript extends that are five levels deep. And you change something at a base level and then everything breaks. So, people were using extends in views to basically share common view behavior. But then they ran into these issues where keys would collide and things would get dropped in unexpected ways. So, behaviors are a way for you to define a pluggable view behavior into view instances such as, imagine you have a view thatâ€™s closeable such as a modal. When you hit the escape key or click on an element with a class of close. You can just add the closeable behavior, things like that. So, Iâ€™d say 2 is very much focused on just improving the developer experience, improving the developer productivity within Marionette. And based on the feedback weâ€™ve gotten and the number of big companies that have switched over, I think itâ€™s been pretty successful. CHUCK:Â  This all sits on top of Backbone? So, itâ€™s a formal model layer for your data, which set, you get change events and whatnot. Marionette is focused on being the view and application layer. So, itâ€™s almost like you will get the MVC, model view controller. Backbone represents the model layer and Marionette is the view and sort of controller layer. I use Angular at work actually. Iâ€™ve been using it for over a year. So, I guess I can stress the fact that with Marionette, if you have a question about how something works or you want to change how something works, you open the annotated source code, you scroll down through the source code which is not large at all, and you read the implementation details. The code, source codeâ€™s heavily commented. And itâ€™s very concise. So, what that means is itâ€™s very hackable and extendable for developers. So, if your application has very specific demands and you want to change how a list shows up. However, when you want to start using I would say, computer science principles that you are familiar with such as you want to use an event emitter, you want to use a registry pattern, itâ€™s kind of hard. You have to wedge it in there in a very strange way. In Marionette, itâ€™s like I want to use this pattern. Itâ€™s very easy to add, because I know how my data flows. I can just add it in. So yeah, I would say that the draw for me is as a programmer I know what I want to do. And I donâ€™t want my tools to get in the way of what I want to do. But since you can pretty much do whatever you want in Marionette, the inspector hooks into all of your views, shows all of your views nested, all of the data, all of the events that have happened in your app, the lifecycle of all of your views. And we make sure that when any method is added, we test it. So, Iâ€™d say after the ecosystem, a test in the ecosystem within an open source library is set up, itâ€™s pretty straightforward. [Chuckles] CHUCK:Â  So, whatâ€™s coming next in Marionette? SAM:Â  Next up. I would say we will be taking a look at formalization of the routing layer and also of the application layer, and seeing how those two can coexist. The routing layer obviously leveraging the great concepts that have been introduced in Angularâ€™s UI router and Emberâ€™s router. And the application sort of taking into account how someone manages starting/stopping applications, how someone manages hooking into routes that start and stop the application and attach data. And the way that weâ€™re positioning all of this is to release these libraries as standalone pieces that people can add today to their applications. And then once we have community buy-in or community validation about these libraries, the next major release of Marionette will probably roll them in. But this allows people to play around with the ideas before theyâ€™re forced to. I guess that raises an interesting point. So, when we decided to release a breaking change in Marionette, itâ€™s a big deal because we changed a ton of code and a lot of methods changed. A lot of concepts changed that would break anyoneâ€™s application of you upgraded. But we wanted to avoid dropping the community, dropping all these people that have done all this work to build with Marionette. So, we spent a long a long time figuring out how we were going to help people upgrade. And you see a lot of people help write upgrade guides, which is like, â€œWe renamed this method to this method and this is why.â€ And we did that. But we went one step further and we actually wrote a tool. Itâ€™s a Python script that you can run against your Marionette application. And it will actually update your code for you. So, it uses some intelligent matching to swap it. And itâ€™ll step through all your code and say, â€œOh, it looks like youâ€™re using an old method. Would you like to change it? Yes, no, or stop.â€ And itâ€™s like an interactive rebase interface. And Iâ€™ve upgraded personally probably 15 applications that have, some of them had many years of time in them. And they all just work. And that was probably the biggest win from the 1.x to the 2.x. And thatâ€™s why just reaching out to the community, we see so very few people are still on 1.x because everyone has made the jump to 2 and has gotten these features for free, which has been great. And it really paid off, all the time that we spent working on this. And I guess I hadnâ€™t seen other libraries actually do that. So, itâ€™s kind of innovative in some ways. Usually itâ€™s, â€œWell, hereâ€™s what we changed. Figure it out on your own,â€ versus, â€œWell, hereâ€™s what we changed and you should use this tool that we wrote to basically upgrade your code for you.â€ DAVE:Â  Thatâ€™s pretty cool.
